page.title: 11Whitworth Rush Cart :1
page.content:
Every September, as part of the Whitworth Fair celebrations, a horse drawn cart, decorated with heather and rushes passes through the streets of Whitworth.
The procession started approximately 300-400 years ago. In those days Parish churches, each surrounded by small villages, were draughty and damp. The rushes were used for warmth and acted as a carpet and in muddy weather they helped to keep the church dry.
Each hamlet cut rushes and took them to church each September because it was harvest and almost winter. The ceremony became a holiday occasion for the community. All the village turned out with all the men in costume and each village had its own dance.
